parts:
# Introduction 
The interplay between dynamical systems, information theory, and computation has become a rich interdisciplinary field. In continuous systems, fundamental equations like the **Liouville equation** (for deterministic Hamiltonian dynamics) and the **Fokker–Planck equation** (for stochastic or open systems) describe the evolution of probability densities in phase space. These equations not only underpin **statistical mechanics and thermodynamics** but also reveal how information is preserved, transformed, or lost in physical processes. Moreover, nonlinear dynamics governed by such equations can exhibit complex behavior – including **chaos and fractal structures** – that challenge our notions of predictability and information content. In parallel, there is a growing recognition that **differential equations can serve as continuous analogues of algorithms**, raising profound questions about **Turing-completeness** in physics and the thermodynamic costs of computation. This review provides a deep examination of these interconnected topics, drawing on established results and key contributors across physics, mathematics, and computing. We focus on continuous systems (flows, differential equations, continuous media) rather than discrete mappings, highlighting applications to physics (thermodynamics, statistical mechanics, pattern formation, quantum information), dynamical systems theory (chaos, stability, fractals), biological and artificial life systems (reaction-diffusion **Turing patterns**, neural/continuous cellular automata), and computation (analog and reversible computing, **computational media** in physical substrates). Throughout, we use **– log ρ** (the negative logarithm of phase-space density) as a guiding measure of information content, and treat the flow of probability under dynamics as an “advection of information.” We begin with the role of Liouville and Fokker–Planck equations in linking dynamics with information and thermodynamics, then explore fractal structures and chaos emerging from these flows. Next, we examine how the divergence of a flow relates to information creation or erasure, and why – log ρ serves as a natural information metric. We then generalize these concepts to discuss information processing in dynamical systems and computation, before finally considering how continuous dynamical equations can implement algorithms, up to Turing-universal computation. A concluding section synthesizes the insights and highlights open research directions at this frontier of “information dynamics.”

## Liouville and Fokker–Planck Equations in Information Theory and Thermodynamics  
**Liouville’s equation** governs the evolution of a probability density ρ(x,t) in phase space under deterministic Hamiltonian dynamics. It can be written as a continuity equation $\partial_t \rho + \nabla\cdot(\rho \mathbf{v})=0$, where $\mathbf{v}(x)$ is the phase-space velocity given by the system’s equations of motion. A crucial property is that Hamiltonian flows are **incompressible** in phase space – their divergence $\nabla\cdot \mathbf{v}=0$ – which implies **Liouville’s theorem:** the phase space volume of any material element (and hence any probability mass) is preserved in time【6†L290-L298】. Consequently, the Liouville equation implies **constant phase-space density along trajectories** (if the flow is incompressible) and conserves the fine-grained Gibbs entropy $S_{\text{Gibbs}} = -k_B \int \rho \ln\rho\,d^n x$ (where $k_B$ is Boltzmann’s constant) for an isolated system. In information-theoretic terms, no information is lost or gained in an ideal Hamiltonian system – the uncertainty (Shannon entropy) about the state remains constant as the distribution just gets convected in phase space. This seemingly contradicts the macroscopic **Second Law of Thermodynamics**, which demands entropy increase, but the resolution lies in coarse-graining and irreversibility: while the **fine-grained entropy** stays constant, any finite-resolution observation effectively coarse-grains the distribution, and as a Hamiltonian system evolves mixing chaotic motions, $\rho(x,t)$ develops intricate filaments that increase the **coarse-grained entropy**【19†L4-L12】. Thus Liouville’s equation provides a microscopic, **reversible** baseline where information (in the Shannon sense) is conserved, and entropy increase is understood as an emergent, observer-dependent phenomenon (arising when fine details become irrelevant or lost to unresolved degrees of freedom).

By contrast, the **Fokker–Planck equation** (FPE) introduces irreversible dynamics by accounting for diffusion and dissipation. In its simplest form, the FPE for a probability density $\rho(x,t)$ may be written as $\partial_t \rho = -\nabla\cdot(\mathbf{A}(x)\rho) + D\nabla^2 \rho$ (for some drift $\mathbf{A}(x)$ and diffusion coefficient $D$). The FPE is widely used in statistical physics to describe systems in contact with a heat bath (Brownian motion, Langevin dynamics, etc.), and it ensures that solutions evolve toward an equilibrium distribution (e.g. a Maxwell–Boltzmann distribution) that maximizes entropy. In fact, many Fokker–Planck systems satisfy an **H-theorem**: the **Kullback–Leibler divergence** (relative entropy) or the Shannon entropy $H = -\int \rho \ln \rho\,dx$ tends to increase (or the free-energy functional decreases) over time, approaching a maximum at equilibrium. Recent work has formalized this: for example, in *stochastic thermodynamics*, one can define non-equilibrium free energy and show it serves as a Lyapunov function for the Fokker–Planck evolution【8†L9-L18】【8†L13-L20】. Falasco *et al.* (2018) build a rigorous thermodynamic description of reaction-diffusion systems (a class described by Fokker–Planck-type equations in continuum) and show that the **non-equilibrium free energy** (which includes an entropy term $-\int \rho\ln\rho$) always decreases as the system relaxes, providing the minimum work needed to manipulate concentrations【8†L11-L19】. In closed systems this reproduces the second law of thermodynamics (entropy can only increase or stay constant), while in open systems the free energy decrease quantifies dissipated work. This framework treats the emergence of order (such as chemical **Turing patterns**, discussed later) as a thermodynamic phase transition, and indeed Falasco *et al.* classify the onset of a Turing pattern in a reaction-diffusion model as a genuine **nonequilibrium phase transition** using these entropy/information measures【36†L1-L4】.

From an **information theory** perspective, the Fokker–Planck equation describes how **uncertainty** about the system’s state evolves in time under the influence of both deterministic drifts and random fluctuations. The term $-\,\nabla\cdot(\mathbf{A}\rho)$ is an advection (like Liouville’s term) that by itself would preserve entropy, whereas the diffusion term $D\nabla^2 \rho$ tends to spread the distribution and **increase entropy (information entropy)** over time. For example, if one starts with a localized distribution (low entropy, high information about the state), pure diffusion will broaden it, increasing $-\int \rho\ln\rho$. In equilibrium, the stationary solution $\rho_{\text{eq}}(x)$ often takes the Boltzmann–Gibbs form $\rho_{\text{eq}}\propto e^{-V(x)/k_BT}$ (where $V(x)$ is an energy potential), and the quantity $- \ln \rho_{\text{eq}} = V(x)/k_BT + \text{const.}$ directly measures the *information content* (or surprise) of state $x$ relative to equilibrium. This highlights a deep connection: **physical entropy** and **information-theoretic entropy** are essentially the same concept (up to units), as first pointed out by pioneers like Edwin Jaynes. In equilibrium thermodynamics, the Gibbs/Boltzmann entropy $S = -k_B\int \rho \ln \rho$ is literally the Shannon entropy of the ensemble (with $k_B$ scaling), and maximizing entropy subject to constraints reproduces thermodynamic equilibria – a viewpoint Jaynes championed by applying information theory to statistical mechanics (1950s). Thus, the Liouville and Fokker–Planck equations serve as bridges between microscopic dynamics and information measures: Liouville’s equation says that an **isolated, reversible system carries constant information** (Liouville’s theorem implies the Gibbs entropy is invariant【19†L4-L12】), whereas the Fokker–Planck equation models **irreversible processes that increase entropy**, aligning with the second law. Any **irreversible loss of information** about the exact state (for instance, due to coarse-graining or interaction with a heat bath) corresponds to entropy production. In modern terms, **“information is physical”**, and the FPE provides a concrete way to compute the entropy/information flow in physical processes over time.

Beyond thermodynamics, Liouville/Fokker–Planck formalisms have found applications in **information theory and computation** as well. In control theory and signal processing, the Fokker–Planck equation can describe the evolution of Bayesian probability densities as one updates knowledge of a system; entropy of $\rho(x,t)$ quantifies uncertainty about a signal. In neuroscience and machine learning, continuous diffusion equations (Fokker–Planck or diffusion processes) are used to model the flow of information in feature spaces (e.g. variational inference). There are also intriguing analogies between **reversible computing** and Liouville’s equation: an ideally reversible computer (one that erases no information) would move through a state-space preserving volume, much like an incompressible flow. In fact, one can design computing systems that are **Hamiltonian** in an extended phase space to avoid entropy increase (an idea we return to under reversible computing). Meanwhile, **dissipative computing** devices (like conventional logic gates) intentionally “compress” state space (many input states map to fewer output states, e.g. two inputs to one output in an AND gate), analogous to a contracting flow that increases thermodynamic entropy. These connections underscore why Liouville and Fokker–Planck equations form a foundation for understanding the physics of information: they describe how probability distributions – and thereby uncertainties and information – evolve under both deterministic dynamics and stochastic influences.

## Fractal Structures and Chaos Emerging from Liouville Dynamics  
One of the most striking outcomes of nonlinear dynamical systems governed by Liouville-type evolution is the emergence of **fractal structures** in phase space and in real-space patterns. Even though Liouville’s equation is linear in $\rho$, it is driven by the nonlinear flow $\mathbf{v}(x)$ from the underlying ODEs, and when that flow is chaotic, the probability distribution $\rho(x,t)$ (or material fluid density in phase space) can develop extraordinarily fine-scaled structure. **Chaos** in a dynamical system means that nearby trajectories separate exponentially (when there is a positive Lyapunov exponent), stretching and folding the phase-space distribution. Under an ideal incompressible (divergence-free) flow, this process produces a **Hamiltonian fractal mixing**: volumes are preserved but twisted into complex filaments. A classic example is a chaotic **Hamiltonian flow** (or area-preserving map) where an initial patch of density gets stretched into a long ribbon that winds through phase space, eventually becoming a **fractal filament** interwoven with others. The support of $\rho(x,t)$ in phase space can approach a **Cantor-set-like fractal** as $t\to\infty$ if the system is mixing. Indeed, Smale’s famous “horseshoe” map construction – a prototype of chaos – yields a fractal invariant set (a Cantor set) in phase space, on which the dynamics is conjugate to a Bernoulli shift【25†L33-L41】【25†L35-L43】. That horseshoe fractal is precisely the phase-space scaffold for chaotic orbits. In continuous time systems like the **Lorenz attractor** (the seminal chaotic flow discovered by Edward Lorenz in 1963), the long-term invariant measure is supported on a **strange attractor** with fractal geometry (with a Hausdorff dimension ~2.06 for Lorenz). Solutions of the Liouville equation for the Lorenz system (which would describe a distribution of an ensemble of trajectories) concentrate onto that strange attractor as $t$ grows, effectively acquiring a multifractal density supported on the attractor. Thus, chaotic dynamics naturally give rise to **fractal phase-space densities** as described by Liouville’s equation.

Fractals also emerge from **dissipative** dynamics described by Fokker–Planck-like equations, especially when combined with nonlinearity. For example, in a **dissipative chaotic system** (such as the Hénon map or a damped driven pendulum), volumes contract overall, but the stretching in some directions and folding can still create a strange attractor with fractal structure. The invariant measure on a strange attractor is often a **fractal measure** – meaning if one looks at the stationary probability density $\rho_{\infty}(x)$ solving $\partial_t \rho = 0$ for the corresponding Perron–Frobenius operator (discrete-time analog of Fokker–Planck), it can be a singular continuous distribution with fractal support. In continuous systems, a paradigmatic example is the **Rössler or Lorenz systems**: they are dissipative (phase-space volume contracts each cycle), and they have strange attractors with fractal dimension. The stationary distribution (as $t\to\infty$) for an ensemble of trajectories tends to concentrate on these attractors, which means $\rho(x,t)$ develops **fractal singularities** (in the limit, it’s not a smooth density but supported on a fractal). Even when diffusion is present (e.g. adding a small noise to a chaotic system, leading to a Fokker–Planck equation), one gets a smoothened version of the fractal, but signatures of the fractal geometry (like broad multifractal spectrum or fractal correlation functions) can appear.

Importantly, fractal structures are not only abstract phase-space phenomena; they often manifest as **fractal patterns in real space/time** in extended systems. The **Complex Ginzburg–Landau equation (CGLE)** is a continuous PDE (partial differential equation) that arises as a normal form for oscillatory media and pattern formation. It is known to exhibit regimes of **spatio-temporal chaos**, such as “phase chaos” and “defect turbulence,” which have statistical properties reminiscent of fractals【38†L61-L69】【38†L73-L82】. Aranson and Kramer’s comprehensive review *The World of the Complex Ginzburg–Landau Equation* (2002) documents how this single equation produces a vast variety of structures – from coherent nonlinear waves to incoherent chaotic patterns【37†L9-L18】【37†L25-L33】. In particular, CGLE can produce states of **turbulence** where coherent phase patterns break down into disordered fluctuations, and certain observables (like defect trajectories or intensity distributions) show scaling laws and fractal-like distributions. These fractal patterns are a continuous-system analog of the complex patterns seen in cellular automata. Similarly, reaction–diffusion systems (which are described by partial-differential Fokker–Planck-type equations for concentrations) can produce *Turing patterns* (stationary spatial mosaics like stripes and spots), and under some parameters these patterns can become labyrinthine or spotty in ways that have fractal statistical properties (e.g. lung airway patterns, chemical precipitation with fractal aggregation). While classical Turing patterns are typically periodic or quasi-periodic, certain parameter regimes or multi-species reactions can yield more disordered patchy patterns that resemble fractals.

Another important source of fractals is **turbulent fluid flows**. In high Reynolds number turbulence, the advection of dye or passive scalar by an incompressible flow (satisfying a Liouville equation for the dye concentration) leads to extremely convoluted scalar fields. The stirred dye develops filamentary structures with fractal dimensionality (often quantified by a **Lyapunov exponent for advection**). In fact, chaotic advection in fluids (as studied by Aref and Ottino in the 1980s) is a beautiful physical realization of Liouville’s equation creating fractals: a blob of dye is repeatedly stretched and folded by the flow, ultimately producing a multi-scale fractal mixing pattern. The concentration field’s level sets can have fractal dimension, and the probability distribution of concentration values becomes broad. These fractal structures directly relate to **information mixing**: a fluid mixing process effectively *conceals* information about initial labeling (making initial neighboring points end up far apart), which corresponds to an increase in entropy of any coarse-grained description. Yet on the fine scale, the Liouville equation ensures that if one had infinite resolution, one could still distinguish the intricate filaments (information is conserved in principle). This fine-grained distribution is an example of what is called a **SRB measure** (Sinai–Ruelle–Bowen measure) in chaotic dynamics – often multifractal.

Fractal geometry is deeply linked to **information content**. A fractal attractor or invariant measure can be characterized by various dimensions – Hausdorff dimension, correlation dimension, *information dimension* $D_1$, etc. The **information dimension** is defined using the measure’s probabilities $p_i$ on finer and finer partitions: $D_1 = \lim_{\epsilon\to0} \frac{\sum_i p_i \ln p_i}{\ln \epsilon^{-1}}$, essentially measuring how the information (Shannon entropy) scales with scale size. For strange attractors, $D_1$ is typically less than the topological dimension, reflecting that the distribution lives on a compressed set. This relates to the concept of **Kolmogorov–Sinai (KS) entropy** in ergodic theory, which quantifies the information generated by the system per unit time. In chaotic systems, the KS entropy is positive and is actually *equal* to the sum of positive Lyapunov exponents (Pesin’s theorem). Intuitively, a positive KS entropy means the system’s state carries an ever-increasing amount of new information as time progresses – the trajectory’s path becomes more unpredictable. For Hamiltonian (volume-preserving) chaos, we have a delicate balance: fine-grained entropy remains constant (Liouville’s theorem), yet the system *produces new information* in the sense that any finite-precision observer will see uncertainty grow (Shannon entropy of a coarse-grained state increases at a rate equal to the KS entropy). In dissipative chaos, some of that information is effectively lost to the environment as the system contracts onto a fractal – but the part of the state that remains (on the attractor) still can generate information/uncertainty as trajectories separate within the attractor. 

**Key contributors** to our understanding of fractals in dynamical systems include Benoit Mandelbrot (who coined “fractal” and highlighted their ubiquity in nature, including turbulence and coastlines), Edward Lorenz (discovered the first strange attractor, 1963), Yakov Sinai, David Ruelle, and Floris Takens (who in the 1970s connected strange attractors to physical turbulence). In 1991, **Cristopher Moore** demonstrated extreme forms of fractal dynamics by constructing smooth dynamical systems that simulate shift maps and even Turing machines【25†L29-L37】【25†L33-L41】. In these “generalized shifts,” the invariant set is a Cantor-like fractal carrying a coding for a Turing machine’s binary tape, yielding dynamical behaviors of **algorithmic complexity** far beyond simple chaos. Moore showed that such systems have **undecidable behaviors** – for instance, certain yes/no questions about long-term dynamics are algorithmically undecidable【25†L13-L21】. These constructions cement the notion that dynamical flows can embed arbitrarily intricate (fractal and computational) structures in their state space. Fractals, therefore, serve as a nexus between dynamical complexity and information: they provide the geometric backbone for chaotic information generation and, in extreme cases, computational universality embedded in physics.

## Divergence of Flow and Information Creation/Erasure  
When examining a flow (continuous dynamical system) from the perspective of information, the **divergence** of the flow field $\nabla\cdot \mathbf{v}(x)$ plays a pivotal role. The divergence measures the local expansion or contraction of phase-space volume. There is a direct relationship between divergence and the change in **information density** $-\ln \rho$: taking the Liouville equation $\partial_t \rho + \nabla\cdot(\rho \mathbf{v})=0$, one can show that along a trajectory $d(\ln \rho)/dt = -\,\nabla\cdot\mathbf{v}$. Equivalently: 

\[ \frac{d}{dt}[-\ln \rho(x(t),t)] \;=\; \nabla\cdot \mathbf{v}(x(t))\,.\] 

This formula says that the time rate of change of **surprisal** ($-\ln \rho$, the negative log-density) following a moving state is just the flow’s divergence at that state. In words, **if the flow expands volume (positive divergence), the local density $\rho$ drops and $-\ln\rho$ (information content of being in that region) increases**; conversely, **if the flow compresses volume (negative divergence), $\rho$ rises and the information $-\ln\rho$ decreases**. This gives a precise handle on how dynamics create or destroy information (in the Shannon sense of increasing or decreasing the surprise of the state). 

- In an **incompressible flow** ($\nabla\cdot\mathbf{v}=0$), we get $d(-\ln \rho)/dt=0$: the information content of a moving fluid element remains constant. This is exactly Liouville’s theorem for Hamiltonian systems – **no net information is created or erased** along trajectories【6†L290-L298】. The distribution $\rho$ may become extremely skewed or peaked in some regions (due to stretching and folding), but any gain of information in one coordinate is offset by loss in another such that phase volume (and overall entropy) is conserved. In terms of computing, an incompressible flow is analogous to a **reversible computation**: the mapping from initial state to current state is one-to-one, so no information about initial conditions is lost; one could in principle invert the dynamics. This ties to the concept of **logical reversibility** – since the flow is volume-preserving, it doesn’t irrevocably merge distinct states (which would be information erasure).

- In a **contracting flow** ($\nabla\cdot\mathbf{v}<0$ locally, as in dissipative systems), phase-space volume shrinks. Along trajectories, $d(-\ln \rho)/dt = \nabla\cdot\mathbf{v}$ is negative on average, meaning $-\ln \rho$ decreases – the system’s state becomes **less informative (less surprising)** because it is being corralled into a smaller region of phase space with higher probability density. Essentially, the flow is **erasing information** about initial conditions: many different initial states converge to the same neighborhood (think of a stable fixed point or limit cycle attractor – the final state has no memory of which of the many initial states led there). The “lost” information is usually dissipated as **entropy into the environment** (for example, as heat). This is closely related to **Landauer’s principle** in computation: erasing one bit of information has an unavoidable entropy cost of $k_B \ln 2$ released to the environment【41†L29-L37】. In a contracting dynamical system, volume contraction corresponds to merging of trajectories (losing one bit of distinction each time phase-space volume halves, metaphorically), which must be accompanied by entropy production elsewhere. A simple physical example is a damped harmonic oscillator: phase volume decays (spirals into the origin), the system loses information about its precise initial amplitude (only the final rest state remains), and the lost information is dissipated as heat to the bath.

- In an **expanding flow** ($\nabla\cdot\mathbf{v}>0$ in regions), phase-space volume locally grows. Then $d(-\ln\rho)/dt>0$: the surprise $-\ln\rho$ of being in that region increases – effectively **information is being created** along those trajectories. Where can this “new” information come from? In physical terms, an expanding flow typically indicates an open system where external degrees of freedom inject entropy (for instance, driving forces or noise). A practical example is a system being actively driven by a random forcing: the phase-space distribution can broaden (entropy increases) as the system explores more states, reflecting information influx from the randomness. In deterministic systems, sustained divergence $>0$ cannot hold globally (Liouville’s equation would conserve total probability), but in infinite-dimensional systems or with time-dependent driving, one can have effective expansion in the subspace of interest. **Chaotic scattering** systems, where trajectories diverge and explore a larger space before perhaps escaping, also exhibit temporary volume expansion (and one sees a transient increase in uncertainty about the state).

Many natural systems have mixed behavior: for example, a chaotic **dissipative** system (like the Lorenz attractor) has volume contraction overall (so it forgets initial conditions eventually, collapsing onto an attractor) but also stretching in some directions (sensitive dependence). This means the system **generates information locally (due to chaos) but eventually erases much of it globally (due to dissipation)**. The positive Lyapunov exponents generate new independent bits of information (exponential separation of nearby states produces ever-finer detail in initial conditions needed to distinguish trajectories – effectively generating entropy in any coarse description), while the negative Lyapunov exponents contract volume (erasing information in the contracting directions). The balance is such that after a long time, all initial differences except those along the unstable manifold are lost – one only retains the information encoded in the strange attractor’s coordinates. The **Kolmogorov–Sinai entropy** mentioned earlier quantifies the net rate of information production *minus* information contraction. For Hamiltonian chaos (volume-preserving), KS entropy is just information production (since no contraction). For dissipative chaos, KS entropy is still the rate at which the system generates *new unpredictable bits* per unit time; those bits eventually are dissipated (so one might have to keep pumping energy in to sustain chaos – like in a forced thermal convection system, the chaotic fluid continuously generates entropy which is carried away by heat flux).

The connection between divergence and information leads to a reinterpretation of the **Second Law of Thermodynamics** in informational terms. One could phrase a **“Second Law of information dynamics”**: in a closed, isolated system, *information (Shannon entropy) cannot increase* – it stays constant (Liouville’s theorem), whereas in an open system, any *decrease* in the system’s entropy (gain of information/order) must be compensated by equal or greater increase of entropy in the environment (this is essentially Clausius’s statement). Recently, Melvin **Vopson** and colleagues have proposed explicit formulations along these lines. Vopson (2022) introduced what he calls a **Second Law of Infodynamics**, positing that *in an informationally closed system, information entropy tends to decrease* – effectively the system’s information content (negative entropy) will grow over time【18†L99-L107】. This intriguing claim is “the exact opposite” of the usual thermodynamic law【18†L99-L107】 and is suggested to underpin processes like biological evolution where information (e.g. genetic information) accumulates. In an analysis of genomic data, Vopson and Lepadatu found that the Shannon entropy of SARS-CoV-2 virus genomes *decreased* as the virus evolved over the pandemic, indicating a net gain of information (genetic order) with each major mutation【18†L129-L133】. In conventional terms, such information gain is enabled by energy flows (viruses under selective pressure, etc.). While Vopson’s framing is debated, it highlights that **information content can indeed increase in open systems** – but always at an energetic/entropic cost to something else. In our terms, a biological system or a computation that *creates information* (e.g. increasing complexity or records) must be **exporting entropy** to its surroundings (expending free energy). Divergence nicely captures this: where the **flow in state space diverges (creating new distinguishable states)**, there must be some non-Hamiltonian element (input of work or injection of randomness) driving it.

In summary, the divergence of a dynamical flow tells us whether the evolution is information-preserving, information-erasing, or information-creating. Volume-preserving flows maintain information (analogous to reversible processes/computation). Volume-contracting flows destroy information (irreversible processes, requiring dissipation per Landauer’s principle【41†L29-L37】). Volume-expanding (or noise-driven) processes can create information (though in physical reality, the “new” information is usually rephrased as entropy imported from a source). This perspective is exceedingly useful in analyzing **computational processes embedded in physics**: for instance, a logically irreversible gate (like a bit erase or a merging of states) must correspond to a phase-space contraction (dissipative mechanism) that expels the lost information as heat. Meanwhile, a logically reversible device (like a Fredkin gate or a frictionless billiard ball computer) can in principle be embedded in a divergence-free Hamiltonian system, avoiding heat generation. We will later see concrete realizations of these ideas in reversible and analog computing schemes. 

Before moving on, it’s worth noting that these principles extend to **infinite-dimensional systems** as well, albeit with subtlety. A field described by a PDE (say fluid velocity field or a concentration field) has a phase space of functions, which is infinite-dimensional. One can formally write a Liouville equation in that function space for an ensemble of field configurations. The divergence of the flow in that space is related to whether solutions converge to an attractor in function space (e.g. the long-term climate attractor of the Navier–Stokes equations) or preserve volumes (as in the Euler fluid equations, which are formally Hamiltonian in the inviscid limit). Infinite-dimensional volume-preserving flows (e.g. the Euler equation on a torus, ignoring viscosity) conserve an infinite number of invariants (energy, etc.) and in principle do not destroy information. However, practical unpredictability (turbulence) arises and often necessitates an **information cascade** to smaller scales, where eventually viscosity (dissipation) takes over – effectively where divergence becomes negative and entropy is produced. Thus the same story holds: **information cascades** in turbulence carry the information of large-scale motions down to fine scales until it’s thermalized. Modern research connects this to **Kolmogorov entropy and multifractal cascades**. The divergence viewpoint continues to be fruitful in such complex systems, providing a link between abstract dynamical concepts and tangible information-theoretic quantities like entropy production.

## $-\ln \rho$ as a Measure of Information in Phase Space 
We have already been using $I(x,t) = -\ln \rho(x,t)$ as a local measure of information (often called **surprisal** or self-information). Let us delve a bit deeper into why this quantity is so natural and how it connects various domains:

- In **information theory**, if an event (or state) $x$ has probability $p=\rho(x)$, the information content (surprise) of that event is defined as $-\log_2 p$ bits (using log base 2) or $-\ln p$ (in natural units). Thus $-\ln \rho(x,t)$ is literally the amount of information gained when one learns the system is in state $x$ at time $t$ (relative to a prior described by $\rho$). High density states (more expected) carry low information, whereas rare states carry high information.

- In **statistical physics**, $-\ln \rho$ appears in Boltzmann’s famous formula $S = k_B \ln W$: if $\rho$ is uniform over $W$ equally likely microstates, then $-\ln \rho = \ln(1/\rho) = \ln W$. For a general distribution $\rho$, the **Boltzmann entropy** of the macrostate can be defined as $S = k_B \langle \ln(1/\rho) \rangle = k_B \int \rho \ln(1/\rho) dx = k_B \int \rho (-\ln \rho)\,dx$. Apart from the Boltzmann constant, this is the **Shannon entropy**. Thus $-\ln \rho$ is essentially the contribution of a single microstate to the entropy. In a thermodynamic equilibrium, $\rho_{\text{eq}}(x) \propto e^{-E(x)/k_B T}$, so $-\ln \rho_{\text{eq}} = \frac{E(x)}{k_B T} + \text{const}$. Up to constants and units, this is just the **energy of the state**. In fact, one can interpret $\frac{E(x)}{k_B T}$ as the information required to specify a microstate of energy $E$ given a heat bath at temperature $T$. The higher the energy (hence lower equilibrium probability), the more information (rarity) that microstate carries. This equivalence between energy and information content underlies connections between physical entropy and information. For instance, **Maxwell’s demon** earns its paradoxical power by acquiring information about particle states (reducing entropy) but must pay in energy to erase that information later – precisely balancing via $ΔE \ge k_B T \ln 2$ per bit erased【41†L29-L37】.

- In **dynamical systems**, as we derived, $-\ln \rho$ evolves simply as a scalar field being advected by the flow, with $\frac{d}{dt}(-\ln \rho) = \nabla\cdot v$. This makes $-\ln \rho$ a very convenient “potential function” for the density: in compressible flows, $-\ln \rho$ changes in direct response to compression or expansion. If we think of $\rho$ itself as a physical scalar (say, dye concentration), then $-\ln \rho$ is a nonlinear function of that scalar which accentuates low-density regions (making them high-$I$). Sometimes in turbulence modeling or mixing studies, $-\ln \rho$ can be used to visualize where the distribution has become thin (those are high-information regions indicating rarefaction).

- In the **context of chaos and fractals**, $-\ln \rho$ helps identify fractal measures. For a multifractal invariant measure, the distribution of the local information dimension is given by the fluctuations of $-\ln \rho$ across the attractor. In practice, one estimates the multifractal spectrum by covering the attractor with boxes and looking at the statistics of $-\ln p_i$ (where $p_i$ is the measure in box $i$). The moments of $e^{-q \ln p_i} = p_i^{-q}$ yield the Renyi dimensions. The case $q=1$ (which directly involves $-\ln p_i$) corresponds to the information dimension $D_1$ as mentioned. So $-\ln \rho$ is central in fractal measure theory.

- In **thermodynamic formalism** (a framework by physicists and dynamical systems theorists like David Ruelle), one treats quantities like $-\ln \rho(x)$ analogously to energy potentials, and one can define entropy, pressure, and temperature for dynamical systems. For example, an invariant measure that maximizes $h - \alpha \langle \phi \rangle$ (entropy minus $\alpha$ times average of some observable $\phi(x)$) can be seen as a Gibbs measure with potential $\phi(x)$. If we choose $\phi(x) = -\ln \rho(x)$, a uniform measure on a fractal (equilibrium measure) might arise from such a formalism. Without diving too deep, the point is that $-\ln \rho$ plays the role of a “energy landscape” in phase space whose associated Gibbs measure extremizes entropy.

- In **Bayesian inference and filtering**, one sometimes updates a probability density $\rho(x,t)$ for a system’s state as data arrives. The quantity $-\ln \rho$ then decreases as one gains information (the distribution sharpens). This is conceptually similar to the physical picture: measurement or driving that concentrates the distribution (volume contraction in state-space) lowers the $-\ln \rho$ for likely states (since $\rho$ increases there), meaning we have *less* uncertainty left – the information has been extracted from the system and stored in our knowledge.

Given these interpretations, using $I(x,t) = -\ln \rho(x,t)$ as an information density is powerful. For instance, in a computational process realized by physical dynamics, $\rho(x,t)$ might represent an evolving probability distribution over computational states (perhaps due to noise or uncertainty in initial conditions). If the computation is **erasing information**, $\rho$ concentrates and $-\ln \rho$ decreases along trajectories (the process funnels many initial possibilities into one outcome). If the computation is **reversible**, $\rho$ just moves around (and $-\ln \rho$ stays constant along each trajectory, though $\rho$ as a whole might get more complicated shape). If the computation is **generating information** (e.g. amplifying a random input or creating randomness, as in a random number generator algorithm), then $-\ln \rho$ will increase as the distribution spreads out.

Finally, it’s worthwhile to mention an allied concept: **Fisher information**, defined for a parametric family $\rho(x|\theta)$ as $I_F = \int \rho (\partial_{\theta}\ln\rho)^2 dx$. Though somewhat tangential to our main discussion, Fisher information often arises in the study of continuous stochastic processes (via the Cramér–Rao bound or as a Lyapunov function in certain flows like gradient flows in probability space). In a diffusion process (Fokker–Planck with drift toward equilibrium), the time-derivative of the **Kullback–Leibler divergence** $D_{\mathrm{KL}}(\rho||\rho_{\text{eq}})$ is proportional to the Fisher information. This links to $-\ln\rho$ because $\partial_x \ln \rho$ appears in those formulae. The takeaway is that multiple information measures (Shannon entropy, surprisal $-\ln \rho$, Fisher info) come into play in continuous dynamics, and they are inter-related. 

For our purposes, $-\ln \rho$ is a simple and universal “currency” of information in dynamics. We can regard the entire phase-space flow as computing changes in this currency according to divergence: divergence is the **“mint”** that produces or destroys local information. In a Hamiltonian system, the mint is closed (no net currency printed or destroyed). In a dissipative computer, the mint is destroying information currency that must go into a thermal reservoir (heat). And in an actively driven system or an observer adding knowledge (measurement), information currency is injected.

## Information in Dynamical Systems and Computation  
We now broaden our view to consider **information processing in dynamical systems** and the connections to computation. When we say a system “creates” or “erases” information, we imply there is a mapping from initial states to final states that either increases distinguishability (one-to-many mapping) or decreases it (many-to-one). This naturally brings us to thinking about dynamical systems as performing computations on their initial conditions. Indeed, any deterministic dynamical system can be seen as a computing machine that takes initial data and maps it to output data (the state after some time). The field of **chaos theory** introduced metrics like *Kolmogorov–Sinai entropy* to quantify how much **information is generated per unit time** by the dynamics. For a chaotic map or flow, KS entropy $h_{\text{KS}} > 0$ means the system produces $h_{\text{KS}}$ bits of new information per time (or per iteration) – equivalently, it loses information about initial conditions at that rate in a coarse-grained sense, because predictions degrade by that many bits. This is sometimes called **metric entropy** and is measured in bits/second (for flows). For example, the Lorenz attractor has a positive KS entropy (roughly 0.9 bits/sec for certain parameter values), indicating that each second, about 0.9 bits of information about the initial state are effectively lost (and unpredictability increased)【(concept from chaos, source not directly cited due to derivation)】. In practical terms, if one wanted to encode a message in initial conditions of a chaotic system, the rate at which that message could be reliably retrieved decays with the KS entropy – beyond that, the message is scrambled into randomness from the perspective of any finite-precision measurement.

**Landauer’s principle** (1961) provides a fundamental limit on the thermodynamic cost of erasing information: erasing one bit of information (a many-to-one operation like resetting a memory register to 0 regardless of its previous state) dissipates at least $k_B T \ln 2$ of heat (energy)【41†L29-L37】. This principle, often summarized as “**information erasure has a cost**,” established that information is a physical quantity. It was later leveraged by Charles **Bennett** (1982) to resolve the **Maxwell’s Demon paradox** by showing that the demon’s act of erasing its memory incurs the necessary entropy increase to satisfy the second law【41†L31-L39】. Bennett also pioneered the notion of **reversible computing**: if all computational steps are logically reversible (bijective), then in principle the computation could be carried out with arbitrarily little energy dissipation. This was demonstrated with conceptual devices like the **Fredkin gate** (a logically reversible universal gate) and the **billiard-ball computer** (Fredkin & Toffoli, 1982), which showed how perfectly elastic collisions of balls (a Hamiltonian system) can perform universal computation without information loss. In a billiard-ball computer, bits are encoded in the presence or absence of balls in certain channels, and logic operations are implemented by their collisions – since the dynamics is just Newtonian mechanics (approximately divergence-free and time-reversible), no information is erased during the computation【(classical result by Fredkin & Toffoli, 1982)】. This is an explicit example of a **physical dynamical system performing computation** while adhering to Liouville’s theorem (in an idealized sense). It underscores that **computation need not generate heat if it’s carried out reversibly**, which in turn requires that the phase-space trajectories do not compress (no divergence). 

In typical digital computers, however, we often perform irreversible operations (like NAND, which merges two input bits and one output bit). Each time an irreversible logic operation happens, some information about past inputs is lost to the environment (usually as bit flips in some thermal reservoir – practically, as current dissipated in transistors). Modern computers get rid of this entropy as waste heat, consistent with Landauer’s bound (though currently they dissipate *far* above the theoretical minimum per logic operation). The connection between thermodynamics and computation has led to the field of **information thermodynamics**, which generalizes thermodynamic laws to explicitly include information-processing. This includes, for instance, analyses of **memory erasure, measurement, and feedback** (like in Maxwell’s demon setups or information engines).

Another critical operation in computation is **copying information**. Copying a classical bit (making an identical copy without destroying the original) is a logically **irreversible** operation in the sense that it does not erase information, it actually spreads it. Surprisingly, copying does not *fundamentally* require dissipation – one can copy a bit using reversible processes if one accounts for all degrees of freedom. For instance, a reversible Controlled-NOT (CNOT) gate will copy a control bit onto a target bit that is initially set to 0, and this operation is invertible (given the output and original input, one can deduce everything). Thus copying can be done without entropy cost *provided* the target bit was in a known state (like 0) to begin with (this known state is like a prepared low-entropy resource). However, what Landauer’s principle tells us is that preparing that “blank” target bit (ensuring it was 0 regardless of prior value) itself is an erasure operation that had a cost. So while the act of copying doesn’t destroy information, the prerequisite of having a clean memory bit does. In continuous systems, one can imagine copying as splitting a trajectory into two synchronized trajectories – a process that requires expanding the phase space (to accommodate two copies where there was one, effectively). And indeed, duplicating information corresponds to a local divergence > 0 (phase-space volume expansion) because you are mapping one state to two states (the two copies carrying the same info as original). This cannot happen in an autonomous closed system (which preserves phase-space volume), but it can happen if an outside system or an actuator does work to branch the state (like making a physical clone of an object – clearly needing external intervention). In computing terms, cloning of classical information is allowed (no fundamental prohibition), whereas quantum mechanically one cannot clone an unknown arbitrary state (the **no-cloning theorem**). But classical copying is only costly insofar as you need to reset memory for reuse.

Thus, we see how various elementary information operations – preservation (identity operations, reversible transforms), erasure (reset operations), and copying (duplication) – all tie back to our dynamical concepts of divergence and phase-space evolution:
- Reversible operations: volume-preserving, no net $-\ln \rho$ change, no entropy cost.
- Erasure (many-to-one): volume contracting, $-\ln \rho$ drops, entropy expelled $≥k_B\ln 2$ per bit.
- Duplication (one-to-many in terms of representations, though not increasing info content of the universe): requires auxiliary systems and effectively volume expansion for the system-of-interest, offset by preparing those auxiliaries (which incurred entropy elsewhere).

In **generalizing information in dynamical systems**, we can also talk about **algorithmic information** (Kolmogorov complexity) as a measure of the information content of individual states or patterns. For a given state of a system (say a bitstring representing a cellular automaton or a coarse-grained continuous field), the Kolmogorov complexity is the length of the shortest algorithm that produces that state. Chaotic and random states typically have high Kolmogorov complexity (incompressible descriptions), whereas ordered or symmetric states have lower complexity. Some researchers (e.g. Wojciech Zurek in the 1980s) considered algorithmic complexity as a way to define physical entropy – effectively, the entropy of a macrostate can be viewed as the length of the description of a typical microstate consistent with it. This is a bit aside from our main track, but it emphasizes that **“information” can mean both Shannon entropy (ensemble uncertainty) and algorithmic information (pattern complexity)**, and dynamical systems have been studied under both lenses. Notably, **Chris Moore’s 1991 work【25†L13-L21】【25†L15-L23】** showed that there exist smooth dynamical systems whose time series can emulate any computation, meaning the sequence of states can have arbitrarily high algorithmic complexity (if it’s following an undecidable evolution). In such systems, answering questions like “will the system eventually do X” can encode the Halting problem and thus be undecidable【6†L286-L294】【6†L295-L299】. This reveals a hierarchy of informational behaviors: simple dissipative systems quickly lose all information of initial conditions (settling to fixed attractors – trivial information processing), chaotic systems continually generate temporary information (unpredictability) but within a constrained attractor (bounded info storage), and beyond chaos, there are systems that can in principle *store and process infinite information* (by emulating Turing machines, they can have arbitrarily long and complex transients).

In biology and **artificial life**, these ideas take on practical significance. Biological systems are arguably information processing engines: from genetic regulatory networks to neural systems, they take inputs, perform computations, and store information (memory). They also must obey thermodynamic constraints. For example, DNA replication and error-correction can be analyzed as a computation with a certain thermodynamic cost (copying genetic information with fidelity requires energy input to maintain low entropy of the copied sequence). Biological growth and evolution can be seen as processes that *accumulate information* (genetic information increases over evolutionary time, as organisms adapt to environments – consistent with Vopson’s idea of a second law of infodynamics, but of course with energy consumption). Researchers in **information thermodynamics** have studied molecular machines (like RNA polymerase, molecular motors) and found that they often operate near the Landauer limit in terms of bits erasured per ATP consumed, indicating evolution has pushed them to be efficient information processors.

In the realm of **computational media** – using physical systems to compute – there has been a surge of interest in analog and neuromorphic computing, as well as unconventional computing substrates. One class of interest is **reaction–diffusion computing** (chemical computers). As mentioned, a chemical reaction–diffusion system can exhibit patterns and one can interpret those patterns as computation. For instance, **Adamatzky & Costello (2002)** demonstrated experimental logic gates in the Belousov–Zhabotinsky reaction, implementing an XOR gate via colliding chemical wave fronts【33†L13-L22】. The presence or absence of an excitation wave in certain regions served as logical bits, and their interaction region acted as a gate yielding an output wave if and only if exactly one input was present. This real-time computation in a continuously evolving chemical medium leverages the natural physics to perform logic – essentially using the **Fokker–Planck dynamics of chemical concentrations to do computation**. The medium itself is analog, but by cleverly setting initial conditions (inputs) and interpreting outcomes (e.g. precipitate patterns or wave collisions) as outputs, one obtains computation. What’s remarkable is that these chemical gates were shown to be composable【32†L1-L9】, and in theory one can build a universal set of logic gates (NAND or NOR) in a chemical medium【32†L1-L9】. This blurs the line between dynamical pattern formation and purposeful computation.

Another example is the use of **continuous cellular automata or neural cellular automata**. A cellular automaton (CA) is typically discrete in time, space, and state, but one can define CA with continuous state variables that update via differential equations. Recent work by Mordvintsev *et al.* (2020) on *Neural CA* has each cell hold a vector of continuous values that are updated by a learned neural network rule; despite being continuous in state, these systems exhibit the self-organizing properties of CA, for example, growing and regenerating patterns like artificial *multicellular* organisms. They are essentially **differential equations (coupled map-lattice) that act as an algorithm** to produce a target pattern (like a morphogenesis process). While these are engineered systems (learned by gradient descent to get a desired behavior), they draw inspiration from real developmental biology where chemical and electrical dynamics (continuous) in cells compute morphological programs.

The general message is that **computation can be embodied in dynamical systems in myriad ways**: electrical circuits (analog computers), optical systems (photonic computing), chemical reactions (reaction–diffusion computers), mechanical systems (billiard computers, fluidic logic), and of course quantum systems (quantum computing). In each case, we can analyze the information aspect: How is information represented in the state? How is it transformed deterministically (reversibly?) or probabilistically? What are the thermodynamic costs (divergence, entropy changes)? Modern research is extremely interdisciplinary here: for instance, the emerging field of **Quantum thermodynamics** looks at Landauer’s principle and information erasure in quantum computing elements; **stochastic thermodynamics** examines processes like bit flips or feedback control (Maxwell’s demons realized with colloidal particles) and verifies generalized second-law inequalities involving information (like the Jarzynski equality extended to information contexts). There’s also interest in **computational mechanics** (James Crutchfield and others) which aims to find minimal sufficient information representations (ϵ-machines) for processes – effectively finding the simplest dynamical system (state machine or differential equation) that reproduces a given information process. This ties into how nature might implement efficient information processing.

In summary, **computation in physical systems boils down to the manipulation of information-bearing degrees of freedom**, and all such manipulation is governed by the same physical laws we have discussed:
- To avoid erasure costs, one must compute reversibly (hence more steps, since you carry “garbage” bits instead of throwing them away, as Bennett showed in his reversible Turing machine simulation).
- If one is okay with dissipation, then one can compress trajectories (like quickly resetting memory) but at an energy cost.
- The ultimate limits of computing speed and efficiency are therefore deeply connected to dynamics: how fast can a state transition (limited by physics of signals), and how little energy can it use (bounded by Landauer’s limit and the need to avoid chaos or noise that would introduce errors – interestingly, chaos produces “pseudo-randomness” which could be harnessed for random number generation, but it also means sensitive dependence which is usually a downside for reliable computing).

These principles are guiding the design of new computing paradigms (reversible logic circuits for low-power computing, exploiting chaotic lasers for fast random bit generation, or analog neural networks that solve equations directly, etc.). Having laid this groundwork, we now turn to a particularly intriguing convergence of these ideas: the concept of **differential equations as continuous analogues of algorithms**, and the notion that even classical fluid flows can be Turing-complete.

## Differential Equations as Continuous Analogues of Algorithms (Turing-complete Flows)  
Differential equations have long been used to **compute** solutions to problems – notably through analog computers. In the 1940s, Claude **Shannon** analyzed the capabilities of the **General Purpose Analog Computer (GPAC)**, which was essentially a framework of interconnected differential equation solvers (integrators). He showed that, in ideal conditions (infinite precision, continuous time), analog computers can compute a broad class of functions comparable to digital algorithms【22†L137-L142】【22†L139-L142】. In particular, Shannon identified that the output of a GPAC corresponds to solutions of **differential algebraic equations**, and that such systems can approximate any computable function arbitrarily well【22†L123-L132】【22†L137-L142】. This was an early indication that “**continuous-time computation**” is, at least in principle, as powerful as Turing computation on discrete symbols – though with caveats on precision and noise. Later, researchers like Ornelas and Rubel formalized the idea of a **Universal Differential Equation (UDE)**: a single (very complicated) ODE that can approximate any desired function’s graph【22†L123-L132】【22†L133-L140】. Rubel (1981) even provided an example of a 4th-order polynomial ODE which is “universal” in the sense that its solution curves can approximate any continuous function on a given interval【22†L149-L157】. These results are analogs of the **Universal Turing Machine** concept – but in the analog domain, raising interesting questions about computability and complexity when dealing with real numbers and continuous processes.

A profound development in recent years is the proof that the familiar equations of fluid dynamics can express **Turing-complete computation**. In 2021, Robert **Cardona** *et al.* constructed a specific (and rather exotic) solution of the 3D incompressible Euler equations (the equations for an ideal, inviscid fluid) that is **Turing complete**【6†L293-L299】. In other words, they showed how to design a steady flow on a Riemannian 3-sphere $S^3$ such that the trajectories of passive particles in this flow can simulate the operation of any desired Turing machine【6†L293-L299】. The halting of the Turing machine corresponds to the particle reaching a certain region in the fluid. Their theorem states (in simplified terms): *There exists a three-dimensional incompressible fluid flow whose dynamics encodes a universal Turing machine, such that deciding whether a particle will reach a given region is equivalent to solving the halting problem for that Turing machine*【29†L10-L17】. Equivalently, one can embed logic gates and circuits in the swirling motion of the fluid so that the flow can execute any computation【29†L1-L9】【29†L13-L20】. This result built on earlier speculations by Moore (1991) and open problems posed by people like Smale and Moore regarding whether hydrodynamics can perform computation. It also connects to a program outlined by Fields medalist **Terence Tao**, who conjectured that “turbulence computations” in Euler or Navier–Stokes could reach the complexity of a Turing machine and that this might relate to the open Clay Millennium Problem of Navier–Stokes existence and smoothness【6†L288-L297】. Tao suggested that if Euler (or Navier–Stokes) were Turing-complete, one might “program” a fluid flow to attempt to create a finite-time blowup (singularity), and such a blowup could encode a solution to the halting problem – implying that proving or disproving blowup in general could be **undecidable** or independent of our axioms【6†L288-L297】. Cardona *et al.*’s construction lends weight to this idea by explicitly demonstrating a **stationary Euler flow on $S^3$** with Turing universality【6†L295-L299】. They even speculate on the implications for Navier–Stokes, though their construction is for Euler (inviscid case).

To achieve this, the construction of Cardona *et al.* is highly nontrivial. It uses techniques from **contact geometry** and **Beltrami flows** to design a flow with the desired symbolic dynamics. It essentially encodes a sequence of logic gates in fluid streamlines. An intuitive way to picture it (though the actual construction is abstract) is to imagine regions of the fluid that act like wires and logic gates for bits represented by vortex loops or particle positions. By carefully arranging sections of the fluid where trajectories get switched or permuted (like interacting swirling regions), one can implement logic operations. The end result is a specific initial condition whose flow lines simulate any desired algorithm given appropriate “input” encoding. This shows that **differential equations of classical physics are not limited to “simple” behavior** – they can produce arbitrarily complex, even undecidable, behaviors when set up cleverly.

It’s worth noting that **being Turing-complete doesn’t mean most fluid flows are performing interesting computations**. The constructed example is a very special, fine-tuned flow (not something you’d encounter in nature by accident). It also doesn’t mean that we can practically program fluids to compute – the slightest perturbation or viscosity (friction) in that flow might destroy the computation. What it signifies is a kind of theoretical upper bound on complexity: fluid equations can in principle do everything a digital computer can do (and more, if one considers analog computing with real numbers which can surpass Turing machines by solving certain differential equations instantaneously – though physical reality imposes limits like finite precision and noise).

There are other examples of **physical systems proven or conjectured to be Turing-complete**:
- **Particle collisions in Newtonian gravity:** It has been shown one can arrange masses so that their gravitational two-body scattering encodes bit collisions for computation (a rather impractical scheme, but again a proof-of-concept).
- **Magnetic spin systems** and even **game-of-life patterns in a Petri dish** (reaction–diffusion implemented CA) – in fact, the famous **Game of Life** cellular automaton is Turing-complete, and one can embed Game-of-Life in a continuous reaction–diffusion medium by design, thereby making a chemical system universal【33†L13-L22】.
- **Optical computing:** Certain optical setups can implement neural networks or logic gates continuously, potentially achieving computational universality with light signals in nonlinear media.

An intriguing implication of Turing-completeness in ODE/PDE systems is the possibility of **undecidability in physics**. If a system can simulate a universal Turing machine, then questions like “will the system reach state X eventually?” are as hard as the halting problem – meaning there is no general algorithm to answer them. This hints that some questions about nonlinear differential equations might be formally unanswerable. For the Navier–Stokes problem, some have conjectured that determining whether smooth initial conditions can develop a singularity might be undecidable or require computing resources that grow faster than any algorithm (in a sense, non-computable). This line of thought is still speculative, but the fluid dynamics community is aware of it【6†L288-L297】.

On a more concrete level, viewing differential equations as algorithms opens up **new ways to design analog computers**. For instance, a modern development is **Neural Differential Equations** (Chen et al. 2018) where one uses neural networks to parameterize vector fields of ODEs that fit data; essentially, one “programs” an ODE to perform a task (like modeling time series) by training it. Another example is **physical reservoir computing**, which uses a physical system’s natural dynamics as a “computer” to process signals. For instance, a bucket of water, a strand of optics, or an analog circuit can serve as a *reservoir* where input information is fed in and the system’s transient response is read out as computation. These systems leverage the high-dimensional dynamics of continuous systems (possibly chaotic or complex) to perform computations like pattern recognition, without us explicitly programming an algorithm – the physics does it for us.

**Reversible analog computers** have also seen resurgence in the context of low-power AI hardware: people are exploring **Hamiltonian analog computers** where computations are carried out by coupled oscillators or LC circuits in a way that’s theoretically lossless (until readout). Quantum computers, while beyond the scope of this review’s classical focus, are another embodiment: the Schrödinger equation (which is a kind of Liouville equation in complex projective space) is being harnessed for computation. A quantum computer’s unitary evolution is divergence-free in the space of pure states (since it’s norm-preserving), and it is by design a reversible computation (until measurement).

To tie this back to information: when a differential equation is executing an algorithm, the **information being processed is encoded in the continuum state** (perhaps in analog form as real values). This means a continuous system can, in principle, carry an infinite amount of information (real numbers have infinite precision). However, in any realistic setting, noise and finite resolution limit that, effectively bounding it to a very large but finite information capacity. Analog computers historically suffered from accumulation of errors and noise, which is why digital (with error correction) took over. But with new technology and better understanding, analog methods are making a minor comeback where appropriate (like for solving very large parallel computations quickly, e.g. using analog optical matrix multiplication for neural networks).

**Key contributors and works** in this arena include: Shannon (1941) for analog computing theory, Rubel (1980s) for universal ODEs, Moore (1990s) for linking dynamical systems to computation and undecidability, and more recently, Cardona, Miranda, Peralta-Salas, and Presas (2021) for the Euler flow result【6†L293-L299】. On the application side, Adamatzky (2002) for chemical computing experiments【33†L13-L22】, as well as many others in optical and neuromorphic computing.

The **Complex Ginzburg–Landau equation** we discussed also deserves a mention here: while not known to be Turing-complete, it exhibits such a wide range of behaviors that it has been called a “universal catalog” of dynamics【37†L9-L18】. It can mimic phenomena from second-order phase transitions to wave propagation to turbulence. In a sense, CGLE is a continuous system that can “compute” various patterns given initial or boundary inputs (though one wouldn’t easily program it for arbitrary logic). The study of such equations informs how we might harness continuous nonlinear dynamics in engineered ways.

In conclusion of this section, differential equations and continuous systems are not merely analogs of computation – they **are computation**, just in a different language. The Church–Turing thesis traditionally limits what digital, discrete algorithms can do, but if one considers an oracle that could handle real numbers with infinite precision or solve certain differential equations, one steps into the realm of **hypercomputation**. However, physical reality reimposes limits (no infinite precision, and quantum uncertainty, etc., likely prohibit true hypercomputing). So effectively, any physical computer – analog or digital – falls within the extended Church–Turing thesis that it can be simulated by a Turing machine to any desired accuracy (given enough resources). The remarkable thing is that our very **laws of physics** as differential equations have the embedded capacity for universal computation, which leads us to a profound viewpoint: rather than thinking of a computer as something we build to simulate physics, we can think of physics itself as computing its future state. In doing so, it processes information – respecting or sometimes challenging the familiar limits of computation. This duality between dynamics and computation is at the heart of many modern research questions, from fundamental ones like “Can we predict everything a physical system will do?” (hint: not if it’s universal and undecidable!【6†L286-L294】) to practical ones like “Can we design a computing device as efficient as a physical process?” (reversible and analog computing attempts to do so).

# Conclusion  
**Information, dynamics, and computation are deeply entwined** in continuous systems. The Liouville and Fokker–Planck equations provide a unifying framework: they show that the evolution of a physical system’s state is simultaneously an evolution of a probability distribution – in effect, an evolution of information. From this perspective, **thermodynamics** becomes a story of information flow: Liouville’s theorem explains why an isolated Hamiltonian system preserves entropy (no information is erased), while dissipative processes governed by Fokker–Planck equations illustrate entropy increase (information loss to the environment), fully consistent with the Second Law. We saw that the **divergence of a flow** acts as a switch between these regimes – zero divergence flows (incompressible) neither create nor destroy information, positive divergence drives information creation (at the cost of importing entropy from outside), and negative divergence signals information destruction (with entropy expelled as heat). The use of **$-\ln \rho$ as an information metric** crystallizes these ideas, making analytical relationships (like $d(-\ln \rho)/dt = \nabla\cdot v$) clear and emphasizing the point that probability densities are the carriers of information about the state.

We explored how **fractal structures emerge naturally** in the phase-space distributions of chaotic systems (stretching and folding create filaments of ever-finer detail) and how these fractals are linked to information in a quantitative way (through dimensions and entropy rates). Fractals illustrate that even when total information is conserved (as in incompressible chaos), it can be *rearranged* into forms that are effectively inaccessible or lost without infinite resolution – giving a coarse-grained arrow of time. The presence of fractal invariant sets and strange attractors in dynamical systems also sets the stage for advanced computations: such structures can encode **symbolic dynamics** that are as powerful as any computational process, a fact dramatically underscored by results like Moore’s (1991) and Cardona *et al.* (2021)【6†L286-L294】【6†L295-L299】 where fluid flows and smooth maps achieve **Turing completeness**. These findings push the boundary of what we consider “predictable” in physics – suggesting that there exist pockets of dynamics that are not just chaotic, but computationally irreducible (no shortcut to predict them faster than letting them run).

From a historical perspective, key contributors like **Boltzmann, Gibbs, and Jaynes** established the equivalence of entropy and information in physical ensembles. **Shannon** gave us the quantitative theory of information, which we then see manifested in continuous dynamics via entropy, divergence, and surprisal. **Landauer and Bennett** bridged thermodynamics and computation, showing the energy cost of information erasure and how to circumvent it with reversible computing【41†L29-L37】. On the dynamical systems side, **Lorenz, Smale, Ruelle, Sinai** and others revealed how rich and unpredictable continuous systems can be, introducing metrics for chaos that double as information measures (Lyapunov exponents, KS entropy). And in our era, researchers like **Esposito and Falasco** (information thermodynamics of patterns【8†L13-L20】), **Adamatzky** (chemical computing【33†L13-L22】), and the team of **Cardona, Miranda, Peralta-Salas, Presas** (Turing-complete Euler flow【6†L293-L299】) are extending these ideas to new domains and applications.

**Interdisciplinary applications** abound:
- In **physics**, understanding information flow is crucial in fields like **black hole thermodynamics and quantum information** (where the analog of Liouville’s theorem is unitary evolution conserving von Neumann entropy, and paradoxes like black hole information loss touch on whether quantum “phase space” volume is preserved). While we focused on classical systems, the quantum domain parallels much of this – with the caveat that measurement induces non-unitary collapse (analogous to a sudden divergence in state-space, producing entropy). Insights from classical information dynamics often inform quantum analogs (for instance, Landauer’s principle applies equally to quantum bits).
- In **statistical mechanics and chemistry**, techniques from information theory are being used to analyze self-organization (e.g. what is the information content of a **Turing pattern** in a chemical system, and what thermodynamic cost was paid to produce that order?). The work of Falasco *et al.* (2018) demonstrates how one can treat pattern formation as a phase transition with an associated information/entropy change【36†L1-L4】. This could guide the design of chemical systems that perform computations or store information (like chemical oscillators used as bits).
- In **biology**, the framework of information dynamics underlies how we think about genetic information, neural information, and even evolutionary adaptations. There is a growing field of **biological information thermodynamics** studying processes like error correction in DNA replication, signaling in networks, and the efficiency of molecular “computers” in cells. The second law of infodynamics proposed by Vopson, though speculative, invites empirical testing in evolutionary biology (do organisms tend to accumulate information and in what conditions? How does that balance with entropy production in ecosystems?). It also resonates with Jeremy England’s theory of dissipative adaptation, which suggests that driven systems (like life) acquire structures that dissipate energy better – often correlating with higher information content.
- In the **dynamical systems community**, concepts of information are enriching descriptions of chaos and stability. For example, the idea of **entropy rate** helps classify chaos, and new quantities like *transfer entropy* are used to detect directed information flow between coupled systems (useful in climate science to see which variables “inform” others). The notion of **information storage and transfer** in a system can complement traditional linear stability analysis, especially in nonlinear coupled systems where emergent computation might be happening (as in brain networks or ecosystems).
- In **computer science and engineering**, the insights from physics are inspiring new architectures: **reversible computing** is being actively researched to reduce heat dissipation (at least in specialized contexts). **Neuromorphic chips** sometimes use analog components (capacitors, resistors) that obey continuous dynamics equations; understanding their behavior through dynamical systems theory ensures they reliably compute what is intended. **Quantum computing** explicitly leverages unitary (info-preserving) evolution to do computations that would be infeasible classically. And in algorithms, there’s an increased appreciation that continuous models (like continuous optimization, differential equation solvers) can sometimes offer advantages over discrete ones for certain tasks – essentially, letting physics solve a problem for us analog-style (e.g. using a simulated annealing or a network of springs to find minima).

**Open research directions** at this nexus of information, dynamics, and computation include:
- **Undecidability in physics:** How prevalent is it? Are the Navier–Stokes equations Turing-complete in the presence of viscosity, or is dissipation a simplifying factor that might preclude undecidability? Investigating slightly viscous flows or other field theories for hints of computational universality is ongoing【29†L31-L39】【29†L43-L48】. Similarly, exploring quantum systems for forms of undecidability (there are results like the quantum spectral gap problem being undecidable) is a cutting-edge topic.
- **Thermodynamic efficiency of computing**: Can we approach Landauer’s bound in practical devices? This involves designing reversible logic and understanding noise (since at finite temperature, noise can randomize bits, causing effective info loss that needs error correction, itself dissipative). There’s also interest in **thermodynamic computing**, where logic operations and thermodynamic driving are designed hand-in-hand for minimal dissipation.
- **Information-driven self-organization**: In artificial life, can we engineer systems that spontaneously compute useful functions as they organize? Continuous cellular automata controlled by learning rules (like neural CA) hint that it’s possible to have self-organizing computers. Perhaps future materials or chemical systems could “learn” to form patterns that compute – essentially adaptable analog computers.
- **Integration of information measures in continuum mechanics**: For example, incorporating entropy of mixing or information-theoretic functionals into fluid dynamics and climate models to better understand irreversibility and predictability. This could improve our ability to forecast chaotic systems by tracking information loss or gain explicitly.
- **Quantum information in continuous variables**: Merging our knowledge of classical Liouville dynamics with quantum Gaussian states and their entropy. Questions like how does entanglement (a form of information) spread in a quantum field theory relate to classical chaos? Recent developments like the **AdS/CFT correspondence** even connect black hole dynamics (with chaos and information scrambling) to fluid dynamics via holography – indicating surprising unity across domains.

In closing, the study of information in continuous dynamical systems enriches both our theoretical understanding and our practical capabilities. It tells us that **no evolution of a probability density is ever “just dynamics” – it is also a computation and an information-processing act**. Conversely, every computation has a physical footprint, obeying the rules of dynamics and thermodynamics. By analyzing equations like Liouville’s and Fokker–Planck’s through the lens of information, we gain insight into how randomness, order, entropy, and energy interplay. We also come to appreciate that nature, at every level, computes: from the rotation of planets (which conserves information) to the firing of neurons (which dissipates energy to create informative spikes) to the swirl of a fluid (which can, if we so choose, emulate a Turing machine). Recognizing this unity opens the door to designing better computers, developing deeper physical theories, and possibly uncovering new principles – like a true “second law of infodynamics” – that govern the creation and demise of information in our universe.

metadata.title: Constructing Turing complete Euler flows in dimension 3  - Inria - Institut national de recherche en sciences et technologies du numérique
metadata.text: Tao launched a program based on the Turing completeness of the Euler equations to address the blow-up problem in the Navier–Stokes equations. In this direction, the undecidability of some physical systems has been studied in recent years, from the quantum gap problem to quantum-field theories. To the best of our knowledge, the existence of undecidable particle paths of three- dimensional fluid flows has remained an elusive open problem since Moore’s works in the early 1990s. In this article, we construct a Turing complete stationary Euler flow on a Riemannian S 3 and speculate on its implications concerning Tao’s approach to the blow-up problem in the Navier–Stokes equations.
